awd_titl_txt: Finding Safe Drinking Water to Mitigate Arsenic Contamination: Tube Wells, Storage, and Diarrhea
awd_abstract_narration:
In an effort to reduce diarrheal disease incidence, public health efforts during the past 30 years have led to an almost universal shift from the consumption of surface water to groundwater from shallow aquifers (<140 feet). The shift to shallow tube wells, however, has exposed tens of millions of people to arsenic, which causes cancer and other health problems. Groundwater arsenic is a major problem in several countries in the Americas and Asia. One mitigation approach has been for households to switch to deep public tube wells that are mostly >500 feet deep because they tap water in an aquifer that is low in arsenic. Although deep tube wells are being installed to reduce exposure to arsenic, the health effects of switching to these often more distant, wells has not been adequately investigated. A concern is that water obtained from a distant well may be stored for a longer period of time in the home, thereby increasing the risk of microbial contamination by extended handling and use. This study provides a comprehensive assessment of whether deep tube wells installed through arsenic mitigation programs are a safe drinking water source in countries groundwater arsenic problem. It also provides insights about the circumstances in which household drinking water storage containers are most likely to be contaminated with waterborne pathogens. Lastly, the study develops a rich database on water, sanitation, hygiene that will be made available and can be linked to another large survey on the health, demographic, and socioeconomic characteristics of the same study population. 

This study integrates theory and methods from the disease ecology tradition of medical geography and environmental microbiology. It combines geographic and environmental microbiology methods with community surveys to provide information that is critical for developing drinking water policies and programs. The objectives of this study are to: (1) determine if deep tube wells protect against diarrheal diseases compared to shallow tube wells, (2) compare the microbial water quality of deep and shallow tube well sources and from household storage containers with water from those wells, and (3) determine if longer travel distance and time to deep tube wells leads to longer duration of water storage, poor water quality in storage containers, and higher diarrheal disease incidence. The study will be conducted in Bangladesh where groundwater arsenic is most severe. A household survey will determine water source, use, storage, hygiene, and sanitation practices. The microbial water quality of tube wells and household water storage containers will be measured for the presence and concentrations of E. coli as fecal indicator bacteria. Distance to tube wells will be measured using a geographic information system database that includes households and tube wells. The analysis will determine if distance/travel time/storage time is related to water quality in storage containers and diarrheal diseases.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigated the effectiveness of deep tubewell interventions to provide safe drinking-water and reduce diarrheal disease risk in under-five children in rural Bangladesh. 

It is estimated that 33-77 million people in rural Bangladesh have been chronically exposed to unsafe levels of arsenic in drinking-water from shallow tubewells, causing some experts to call it the largest mass poisoning in history. To mitigate arsenic exposure, thousands of deep tubewells that tap into the deeper arsenic-free aquifer greater than 500 feet have been installed throughout arsenic affected areas. However, the health effects of deep tubewell use are not well understood and there are concerns that reliance on these more expensive and often less accessible tubewells may have unintended health consequences. Our project asked the following questions.  Do deep tubewells provide better drinking-water quality, and does that translate to better health outcomes? And if so, are those benefits (or harms) equitably distributed among places and populations in rural Bangladesh? What is the context under which these deep tubewells work best?

The intellectual merit and broader impacts of the project have been established through multiple publications, conference presentations, workshops, mentoring, and capacity building at the research center we collaborated with in Bangladesh, icddr,b. The project findings and publications have made theoretical and applied contributions to the subfield of health and medical geography, and beyond. This project has helped advance our understanding of geography of health interventions, that seeks to examine the geographic context underlying population health interventions. Although impact evaluation of health interventions is an established field, there are overlooked challenges such as: 1) potential for unintended health consequences, and 2) spatial variation in the effectiveness of an intervention. We showed that although deep tubewells have comparable quality at the tubewell source to shallow tubewells, households that use a deep tubewell may be exposed to higher microbial contamination due to factors such as longer time taken to collect water, longer storage times, and risky storage container handling such as using surface water for washing. This suggests potential for unintended harm due to increased exposure to microbial contamination. Importantly, we also found that although deep tubewell use is linked to reduced diarrheal disease incidence, the benefits of deep tubewells are unequally distributed. While deep tubewells are effective in areas vulnerable to groundwater contamination, and in areas where access to shallow tubewells is limited, they are inequitably distributed and often concentrated in areas where they may not be needed as much. Our work has contributed to debates among health intervention experts in different disciplines and among stakeholders in Bangladesh that are involved with the scale up of deep tubewell installations in Bangladesh and beyond.

The project has resulted in 4 published journal papers, with 2 more under review, and 8 conference papers and presentations both domestic and international. In addition, the findings of this project led to two policy workshops to evaluate how our results can be used to inform arsenic mitigation efforts in Bangladesh and beyond. In addition to these outcomes, we also created a linked database that integrates all study data with the Matlab health and demographic surveillance data housed at icddr,b. The Matlab health and demographic surveillance data is the longest running longitudinal surveillance system in the world, and our linked dataset will help future researchers and practitioners follow health outcomes among cohorts of households using deep tubewells.

In addition to the intellectual merits and broader impacts described above, this project has involved significant collaboration and mentoring among both graduate students and undergraduate students at UNC Chapel Hill and at icddr,b, Bangladesh, who have also collaborated and co-authored several of the papers. The project provided training for one PhD student who completed his dissertation on the topic and is now a postdoc at UNC Chapel Hill. In addition, three other graduate students also worked on the project and are co-authors on the papers. Through a Research Experiences for Undergraduates (NSF-REU) supplement, the project also mentored and supported 4 undergraduate students who worked on the project. These students learned how to conduct literature reviews and conduct exploratory statistical analysis and utilized their skills in data analysis on co-authored peer-reviewed papers. All of students have graduated since, with three pursuing graduate degrees in health geography and epidemiology. In addition to students in the US, the project also supported two research assistants at icddr,b Bangladesh, which provided training for research careers and they were also co-authors on the published papers. Finally, the project has also provided teaching materials for the investigators and the postdoc for their undergraduate classes such as Introduction to Health and Medical Geography, Political Ecology of Disease, Spatial Data Science, and graduate classes such GIS and Public Health.
